Description: Corinthian black-figured pottery column-krater reconstructed from numerous fragments and added plaster; interior: glazed black (mostly fired red); exterior: on top of flat rim, ray pattern; black around edge; reserved on underside; black around neck; on each handle plate: black-figure swan, to right; glaze on edge and underside of plates and on handles; below each handle plate, possibly griffin-headed bird, to right; on Side A of body: serpent between two confronting cocks; on Side B, bird flying to right between confronting horsemen; behind each horse a small flying bird; below, animal frieze consisting of alternating grazing deer to right and panthers to left; below, wide black band above rays (base of krater and foot are modern). Dedication to Aphrodite on lip.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context ΦA (Well 1) or ΦB (Well 2) later fill before Temple 2(?)
Curator's comments: The Greek and Roman Department's Register of Antiquities states that the krater was found at Naukratis with no further details; but according to Gardner it was found in the region of the Sanctuary of Aphrodite, and the inscription on the surface of the rim is a dedication to her. It seems assured therefore, that the krater was originally, at any rate, located there.
Amyx (1988), p. 319 tentatively attributes the krater to the Detroit Painter.
Bibliographic references: Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 219, no. 46)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 101, no. A153)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.008) (Phase 1)
Gardner 1888 / Naukratis II (pp. 40, 46, pl. X, pl. XXI, no. 780)
